welcome.title: Pick a Linux distro that fits your choices
welcome.tagline: This is a compatibility-based picker. It never ranks or recommends — it only filters based on what you select.

expect.title: What you can expect
expect.intro: Pick Your Linux is an open, compatibility-first project: you answer clear questions, we apply explicit filters, and you get a shortlist with transparent reasons.
bullets: No rankings or opinions — just compatibility.
Clear reasons for every result.
Stop anytime or refine later.

welcome.quickPhase: You can stop after the quick phase and still get results.

complete.title: You are ready for results
complete.tagline: See the compatible shortlist based on what you selected.

phaseGate.tagline: You can keep refining or jump to results now.

results.title: Your compatible shortlist
results.tagline: These results are compatible with your choices. There are no rankings or scores.

explainability.title: Explainability & control
explainability.tagline: Review answers or see why some distros were excluded.

distroCard.noStrictFiltersMatched: No strict filters were active for this result.

disqualified.title: We stopped the flow
disqualified.tagline: One of your answers triggered a hard stop. Linux may not fit these constraints as stated. You can restart or adjust an answer to explore other outcomes.

howItWorks.title: How it works
howItWorks.tagline: This site does not pick a single “best” Linux version. It only shows what fits the answers you give.

sections.title: 1) Pick how deep you want to go
sections.content: Start with a quick set of questions. If you want more accuracy, you can keep refining. You can also stop after the first phase and still get results.

sections.title: 2) You answer plain questions
sections.content: We ask about things like whether you want everything to work without using the terminal, whether you need proprietary software, or whether your computer is older.

sections.title: 3) Optional refinements (if you choose)
sections.content: The next phase explains a few concepts in beginner terms:
bullets: Desktop preference = the look and layout of the interface.
Release model = how updates arrive (fixed batches vs rolling updates).
No preference = don’t filter on that attribute.

sections.title: 4) We filter based on your choices
sections.content: Your answers become clear, fixed constraints. Every Linux version is checked against those constraints. If it doesn’t meet them, it is excluded. Nothing is ranked or scored.

sections.title: 5) Multiple results are normal
sections.content: Many Linux versions can satisfy the same constraints. That is expected. We show a compatible shortlist first, and you can expand it or review the reasons for each result.

sections.title: What we do not do
bullets: We do not choose favorites.
We do not rank or score Linux versions.
We do not add hidden weights or personal opinions.

howItWorksDocs.title: How It Works
howItWorksDocs.tagline: This page is a docs-driven overview of the decision engine, data model, and explainability rules behind Pick Your Linux.

sections.title: 1. Product Promise
sections.summary: Pick Your Linux is a deterministic compatibility engine. It does not rank, score, or suggest a single best distro. It only filters with explicit rules and shows transparent reasons.
bullets: Multiple matches are expected when multiple distros satisfy the same constraints.
No hidden weights, popularity scores, or subjective recommendations are used.
You can change answers and immediately see how outcomes change.

sections.title: 2. Core Architecture
sections.summary: The system is split into strict layers to keep logic testable and UI dumb.
bullets: Data layer (/src/data): schemas, question catalog, distro dataset.
Logic layer (/src/engine/logic.ts): pure condition and patch evaluation.
State layer (/src/engine/state.ts): flow orchestration, progress, undo, results view models.
UI layer (/src/components): render-only components that consume view models.
Import direction is one-way: UI -> state -> logic.

sections.title: 3. Data Contract (UserIntent)
sections.summary: Every answer updates a single validated UserIntent object. This is the decision state.
bullets: Installation and maintenance preferences define setup and post-install friction tolerance.
Proprietary preference controls acceptance of closed-source components.
Hardware context includes architecture, RAM, secure boot, and GPU details.
Use-case tags include Gaming, Privacy, Work, Server, and OldHardware.
Optional refinement fields include desktop preference, release model, init system, and package manager.

sections.title: 4. Question Engine
sections.summary: Questions are data-driven. Each option contains deterministic JSON patches. Visibility is controlled only by explicit conditions.
bullets: Allowed patch ops: set, add_tag, remove_tag.
Allowed condition ops: eq, neq, in, contains, and, or.
No functions in data, no callbacks, and no runtime eval.
Question order and phase behavior come from the catalog, not UI logic.

sections.title: 5. Phased Journey
sections.summary: Flow depth is progressive and forward-only: Quick (Beginner) -> Intermediate -> Advanced.
bullets: Quick gathers high-signal constraints with minimal time.
Intermediate adds practical refinements (desktop style, update model, hardware clarifiers).
Advanced adds explicit system preferences (init, package manager, stricter controls).
Users can stop at results after quick/intermediate and continue refining later without restart.

sections.title: 6. Hard Constraints (Pass/Fail)
sections.summary: Hard constraints exclude incompatible distros. If a distro fails one hard rule, it is out.
bullets: GUI installer requirement excludes manual-installer distros.
No-terminal maintenance requirement excludes hands-on maintenance distros.
Avoid proprietary excludes distros requiring proprietary support.
Require proprietary excludes distros with no proprietary support.
Old hardware requirement excludes distros not suitable for low-end/older hardware.
Secure boot and NVIDIA preferences apply additional explicit compatibility checks.

sections.title: 7. Soft Compatibility Reasons
sections.summary: Soft reasons do not rank distros. They only explain why a compatible distro may fit better for specific goals.
bullets: Gaming and privacy posture generate explainability reasons.
Desktop/release/init/package-manager preferences add explicit match reasons.
Choice-driven reasons and strict-filter matches are shown separately in results.

sections.title: 8. Results and Explainability
sections.summary: Results are presented as compatibility outcomes, not recommendations.
bullets: Each card includes strict filters matched, choice-driven reasons, and potential friction.
Explainability panel shows active constraints and excluded distro reasons.
Compare page exposes distro attributes side-by-side using the same source data.
Sorting defaults to most matches first; user filters are explicit and reversible.

sections.title: 9. Data Quality and Audits
sections.summary: Distro data follows schema validation plus consistency audits.
bullets: Schema validation enforces legal values for every distro attribute.
Audit rules flag suspect combinations (for example NVIDIA support vs proprietary policy).
Secure boot claims and rolling-maintenance expectations are audited for defensibility.

sections.title: 10. Testing and Validation Gates
sections.summary: Changes are expected to pass deterministic validation pipelines.
bullets: Flow validator checks that question visibility and transitions are coherent.
Question and distro validators enforce schema and catalog integrity.
Engine tests cover condition logic, patch behavior, completion, and undo.
The goal is explainable and reproducible behavior under strict typing and schema control.

sections.title: 11. UX and Copy Rules
sections.summary: Language is designed for clarity and reversibility.
bullets: Avoid words like best, top, recommended, or popularity-driven claims.
Avoid skill-judgment framing in the UI; focus on comfort and goals.
Every choice should feel reversible: review answers, edit, or restart.
